content: you may need to indicate that nature "nothing" need to print as "quadrilateral".

I thought I'd already seen this here, but actually I'm mixing it up with this other one: http://codegolf.stackexchange.com/q/1487/199

I foresee ambiguity in the quadrilateral naming (ABCD or BCDA?) (or even DCBA?) It appears to be always "in the order they're given".

My preferred alteration would be to just drop the vertex names altogether and only ask for the nature (no sentence either), since I see this more as a geometry problem than a parsing one.
But I'd settle for a statement that the expected quadrilateral is literally the provided vertices, in order, if really you want that part in.

Thank you for thinking of degenerate cases before I got there :)

Why the limitation to 3 quadrilaterals per test?

Crap, my other solution won't port here. Oh well, upvoting anyway.

Nice :)
Naming the vertices doesn't seem all that useful here, it just adds clutter to the main algorithm, especially since there are no trick cases (always ABCD or EFGH - maybe this is for golfing purposes?)

I can change the names if you like. ;-)
Done.
Note that the triangle version of this one is harder.

Why 3? I don’t know.
The parsing part is not hard, you just have to copy the vertices in the same order.
Don’t forget the triangle puzzle, a bit harder.

Why do people always interpret my commenting as "it's too hard"?!

It's not too hard. It's simply inappropriate here. In my opinion anyway. Oh well.

I built this puzzle as a schoolish question.
You are a pupil and your teacher’s asking you a question about a quadrilateral.
You should answer with a correct sentence.

I'm a pupil and I answer DCBA is a square. The teacher answers: No, JBM, DCBA isn't a square, the correct answer is ABCD is a square.
Childish teacher.
